facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 678 and 679 of 1963 are before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 678 and 679 of 1963. Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 4, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in Tax

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated April 4, 1961 of Kerala High Court in Tax Revision Nos. 52 and 53 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated April 4, 1961 of the Kerala High Court in Tax Revision Nos. 52 53 1959. B. Pai, T. N. Ramachandra, J. B. Dadachanji, O. C. Mathur and Ravinder Narain, for the appellants  in all the appeals .

facts.text: Appellant owns several estates wherein tea is grown.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant owns several estates wherein inter alia tea is grown and was assessed to sales-tax in respect of the tea sold by it during the years 1954-55 and 1955-56, by the Sales Tax Officer, First Circle, Quilon in the State of Travancore-Cochin by his order dated December 23. 1956.

facts.text: Appellant assessed to sales-tax on tea sold during 1954-55 and 1955-56 by Sales Tax Officer, First Circle, Quilon, Travancore-Cochin, order dated December 23, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant owns several estates wherein inter alia tea is grown and was assessed to sales-tax in respect of the tea sold by it during the years 1954-55 and 1955-56, by the Sales Tax Officer, First Circle, Quilon in the State of Travancore-Cochin by his order dated December 23. 1956.

facts.text: Taxable turnover included sales of tea by auction at Fort Cochin.

anchor.surface_text: In the taxable turnover on which sales tax was companyputed by the assessing authority were included two items which are the subject of companyplaint in these two appeals which relate to these two years of assessment.

facts.text: Appellant claimed auction sales of tea at Fort Cochin (Madras State) were outside Travancore-Cochin and exempt under Art. 286(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: Before the assessing officer the appellant claimed that certain sales of its tea which were companyducted by auction at Fort Cochin-a place which at the relevant date was in the Madras State, were sales outside the Travancore-Cochin State and that companysequently these sales were exempted from taxation by the State of Travan- companye-Cochin under Art. 286 l - a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer rejected appellant's contention and included auction sales in taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer rejected this companytention and included the sum involved in these sales in the taxable turnover.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner failed; held tea in godowns at Willingdon Island (Travancore-Cochin) so sales deemed within state.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal filed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner also failed, this authority holding that as the tea sold was, at the date of the auction, admittedly in godowns in Willingdon Island in the State of Travancore-Cochin, the sales must be deemed to have taken place within taxing State by virtue of a provision in the State Sales Tax Act to which we shall refer later and hence liable to be included in the taxable turnover.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal upheld appellant's contention, set aside inclusion of auction sales turnover: Rs. 56,43,184/11/ for 1954-55, Rs. 62,13,604/3/ for 1955-56, remanded excluding these.

anchor.surface_text: There was a further appeal taken by the Appellant to the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal which upheld the appel- lants companytention and set aside the assessment in so far as it included the turnover relating to the auction sales of tea held at Fort Cochin, this turnover amounting to Rs. 56,43,184/11/in regard to the assessment year 1954-55 and Rs. 62,13,604/3/in regard to the assessment year 1955-56 and remanded the case for fresh disposal by excluding these sums from the companyputation of the taxable turnover.

facts.text: State filed revision to Kerala High Court under s.15(b) General Sales Tax Act Travancore-Cochin; High Court allowed, upheld STO and AAC.

anchor.surface_text: A revision petition was thereafter filed before the High Court by the State under s. 15 b  of the General Sales Tax Act of Travancore-Cochin and the learned Judges allowed the Revision and upheld the order of the assessing officer and the Appellate Commissioner holding the turnover represented by these auction sales to be validly taxable under the State law relating to sales tax.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied to the High Court for a certificate of fitness and this having been granted the appeals are number before us.

facts.text: Tea sales concluded at Fort Cochin, goods stocked in godowns in Travancore-Cochin State, deliveries from godowns in Willingdon Island.

anchor.surface_text: The facts in relation to the transaction relating to the sale of the tea and which the learned Judges of the High Court held number to be an outside sale may be stated in their own words - The sales of teas were companycluded at Fort Cochin and the goods were stocked in godowns situated in the Travancore Cochin State.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal found property in goods passed at Fort Cochin on fall of hammer at auction.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal has companye to the companyclusion that the ownership of the companymodity having passed in Fort Cochin, the property had number passed within the taxing State, accordingly they would be outside sales for purpose of Art. 286 1  and exempt from taxation.

facts.text: Kerala High Court proceeded on basis that property passed at Fort Cochin on fall of hammer.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal had recorded a finding that the property in the goods sold passed at Fort Cochin on the fall of the hammer at the auction and the learned Judges of the High Court proceeded on the same basis.

facts.text: In A.V. Thomas Co. case, Kerala High Court held Explanation 2 to s.2(j) not violative of Art. 286(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up before the High Court the position was, that that Court had after a review of most of the earlier cases which had been referred to by the Tribunal, held in Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales- tax, Trivandrum v. A.V. Thomas Co. 1  that the word outside sale in Art. 286 1  a  had numberreference exclusively to the transfer of the property in the goods according to the provisions of the Sales of Goods Act, and therefore that Explanation 2 to s. 2 j  was number violative of Art. 286 1  a  and that if at the moment when the property passed, it number being very relevant where the property passed, the goods were in the State of Travancore-Cochin, then it was number an outside sale quoad Travancore Cochin and companyld be subjected to salestax by that State.

facts.text: Supreme Court reversed Kerala High Court in A.V. Thomas Co. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner (1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 608).

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Salestax, Trivandrum v. A. V. Thomas Co. 1  was brought before this Court on appeal and has been reversed  See A.V. Thomas CO. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax, Trivandrum 3 .

facts.text: In A.V. Thomas case, title to goods passed at Fort Cochin, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It has been foundand it has number been disputed that the title to the goods in the present case passed at Fort Cochin the question is whether the sale was outside sale or inside sale as the expressions have been companypendiously used in various judgments to indicate sales taking place within a State or without it.

facts.text: Supreme Court held sale outside Travancore-Cochin as title passed at Fort Cochin (Madras).

anchor.surface_text: After referring to the decision in the India Copper Corpo- ration Ltd. v. State of Bihar  1  the Court held that the sale in the case before them was an outside sale quoad TravancoreCochin, because the title passed at Fort Cochin in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal held auction sales of full lots were of ascertained goods, complete on fall of hammer, took place in Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal recorded a finding on this matter in these terms The question whether the sales took place outside the State or number will have to be decided on the basis of the general law relating to sale of goods. We hold that in the case of auction sales of full lots the sales were of ascertained goods and hence became companyplete on the fall of the hammer and that the sales took Place within the Madras State.

facts.text: Point whether property passed at Fort Cochin not argued before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the revision application which the department filed to the High Court this question Whether the property in the goods  1  1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 608. did pass at Fort Cochin was raised but nevertheless the argument before the High Court proceeded wholly on the basis of the companyrectness of the finding by the Appellate Tribunal that the property in the teas did pass on the fall of the hammer at Fort Cochin.

facts.text: Supreme Court declined to permit respondent to argue property did not pass at Fort Cochin, as not urged before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we declined to permit learned Counsel for the respondent to urge any ground relating to the property in the goods in the teas sold number having passed in Fort Cochin in the Madras State to be raised, as the point which is number one of pure law was number urged before the learned fudges of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeals, reversed High Court, restored Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are, therefore, allowed and the, order of the High Court reversed and that of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal restored.

facts.text: In A.V. Thomas case, chests of tea stored at Willingdon Island (Travancore-Cochin), auctions at Fort Cochin (Madras), delivery orders at Fort Cochin, delivery at warehouses, then sent elsewhere or exported.

anchor.surface_text: In A. V. Thomas Co. Ltd.s case 1  chests of tea were stored in warehouses at Willingdon Island in the Travancore- Cochin State, but auctions of the tea chests were held at Fort Cochin which was at the material time within the State of Madras, and after the price was paid at Fort Cochin delivery orders were given to the purchasers addressed to the warehouse-keepers at Willingdon Island and actual delivery was given at the warehouses.

facts.text: Facts in present case substantially same as A.V. Thomas Co. case.

anchor.surface_text: As the fact which give rise to this case are substantially the same as the facts on which a. V. Thomas Co. Ltd.s case 1  was decided, the decision of the appeals must be in favour of the assessee.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 20, 1964 by Ayyangar J., Shah J. separate opinion.

anchor.surface_text: March 20, 1964. The judgment of GAJENDRAGADKAR,C.J., WANCHOO, RAJAGOPALA AYYANGAR AND SIKRI, JJ. was delivered by AYYANGAR J. SHAH, J. delivered a separate Opinion.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH. J.-If the question raised in these appeals were res integra, I would hold that the price obtained at auction sales of tea held at Fort Cochin when the goods were lying in warehouses in the Travancore-Cochin State was liable to be taxed under the General Sales Tax Act ... did not altogether exclude the doctrine of territorial nexus in its application to salestax legislation.

arguments.claim: 'Outside sale' in Art. 286(1)(a) not exclusively where property passes per Sale of Goods Act; Explanation 2 to s.2(j) not violative; if goods in Travancore-Cochin when property passes, not outside sale, taxable.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up before the High Court the position was, that that Court had after a review of most of the earlier cases which had been referred to by the Tribunal, held in Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales- tax, Trivandrum v. A.V. Thomas Co. that the word outside sale in Art. 286(1)(a) had no reference exclusively to the transfer of the property in the goods according to the provisions of the Sales of Goods Act, and therefore that Explanation 2 to s. 2(j) was not violative of Art. 286(1)(a) and that if at the moment when the property passed, it not being very relevant where the property passed, the goods were in the State of Travancore-Cochin, then it was not an outside sale quoad Travancore Cochin and could be subjected to sales-tax by that State.

holdings.text: The auction sales of tea conducted at Fort Cochin are outside sales within the meaning of Article 286(1)(a) of the Constitution and cannot be taxed by the State of Travancore-Cochin as the property in the goods passed at Fort Cochin in the Madras State.

anchor.surface_text: Now the question is can a sale of the tea effected by the Appellant by auction at Fort Cochin and which were included in its taxable turnover be said to be outside the State? The facts in relation to the transaction relating to the sale of the tea and which the learned Judges of the High Court held not to be an outside sale may be stated in their own words - The sales of teas were concluded at Fort Cochin and the goods were stocked in godowns situated in the Travancore Cochin State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying settled law from India Copper Corporation and A.V. Thomas & Co. (SC) that for non-Explanation sales under Art. 286(1)(a), situs determined by where property passes; facts identical to A.V. Thomas where title passed at Fort Cochin.

holdings.text: The view of the Kerala High Court that Explanation 2 to s.2(j) of the General Sales Tax Act is not violative of Art. 286(1)(a) and permits taxation if goods are in the state when property passes is incorrect.

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration in the appeal is the correctness of the view expressed by the High Court. The decision in Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Salestax, Trivandrum v. A. V. Thomas Co. was brought before this Court on appeal and has been reversed See A.V. Thomas CO. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax, Trivandrum .

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's decision in A.V. Thomas reversed by Supreme Court; law settled that situs of non-Explanation sale is where property passes, overriding state deeming provision.

holdings.text: Respondent not permitted to argue that property in goods did not pass at Fort Cochin, as this point was not urged before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, we declined to permit learned Counsel for the respondent to urge any ground relating to the property in the goods in the teas sold not having passed in Fort Cochin in the Madras State to be raised, as the point which is not one of pure law was not urged before the learned fudges of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point raised below but not argued before High Court; Supreme Court declines to entertain new argument on fact/mixed question not pressed earlier.

holdings.text: The appeals are allowed, the judgment of the High Court is reversed, and the order of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal is restored.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals are, therefore, allowed and the, order of the High Court reversed and that of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct consequence of holdings on situs of sale and procedural bar; restores lower tribunal's exclusion of auction turnover from taxable turnover.

holdings.text: Article 286(1)(a) and its Explanation, prior to the Sixth Amendment, did not exclude the doctrine of territorial nexus for taxing non-Explanation sales where sufficient territorial connection exists, such as goods being within the state at the time of contract.

anchor.surface_text: SHAH. J.-If the question raised in these appeals were res integra, I would hold that the price obtained at auction sales of tea held at Fort Cochin when the goods were lying in warehouses in the Travancore-Cochin State was liable to be taxed under the General Sales Tax Act ... did not altogether exclude the doctrine of territorial nexus in its application to salestax legislation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurring opinion; if res integra, territorial nexus (precedent from pre-Constitution cases like Tata Iron & Steel) survives Art. 286 for non-Explanation sales; goods location provides nexus; but bound by precedent in A.V. Thomas limiting to passing of property.

anchor.surface_text: Now the question is can a sale of the tea effected by the Appellant by auction at Fort Cochin and which were included in its taxable turnover be said to be outside the State? The facts in relation to the transaction relating to the sale of the tea and which the learned Judges of the High Court held not to be an outside sale may be stated in their own words - The sales of teas were concluded at Fort Cochin and the goods were stocked in godowns situated in the Travancore Cochin State.

The appeals are, therefore, allowed and the, order of the High Court reversed and that of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal restored. The appellant will have his companyts here and in the High Court-one hearing

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration in the appeal is the correctness of the view expressed by the High Court. The decision in Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Salestax, Trivandrum v. A. V. Thomas Co. was brought before this Court on appeal and has been reversed See A.V. Thomas CO. Ltd. v. Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax and Sales-tax, Trivandrum .

The appeals are, therefore, allowed and the, order of the High Court reversed and that of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal restored. The appellant will have his companyts here and in the High Court-one hearing

In these circumstances, we declined to permit learned Counsel for the respondent to urge any ground relating to the property in the goods in the teas sold not having passed in Fort Cochin in the Madras State to be raised, as the point which is not one of pure law was not urged before the learned fudges of the High Court.

The appeals are, therefore, allowed and the, order of the High Court reversed and that of the Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal restored. The appellant will have his companyts here and in the High Court-one hearing

anchor.surface_text: SHAH. J.-If the question raised in these appeals were res integra, I would hold that the price obtained at auction sales of tea held at Fort Cochin when the goods were lying in warehouses in the Travancore-Cochin State was liable to be taxed under the General Sales Tax Act ... did not altogether exclude the doctrine of territorial nexus in its application to salestax legislation.
